In this paper, we propose PE-GNN, a new framework that incorporates spatial context and correlation explicitly into models. Building on recent advances in geospatial auxiliary task learning and semantic spatial embeddings, our proposed method (1) learns a context-aware vector encoding of geographic coordinates and (2) predicts spatial autocorrelation in the data in parallel with the main task. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on two climate-relevant regression tasks: 3D spatial interpolation and air temperature prediction. The code for this study can be accessed via: https://github.com/konstantinklemmer/pe-gnn.

1. Introduction

Geographic data is characterized by a natural geometric structure, which often strongly affects the observed spatial pattern. While traditional neural network approaches do not have an intuition to account for spatial dynamics, graph neural networks (GNNs) can represent spatial structures graphically. Recent years have seen many applications leveraging GNNs for climate-related modeling tasks in the geographic domain, such as precipitation forecasting and traffic modeling. However, as we show in this study, GNNs are not necessarily sufficient for modeling complex spatial effects: spatial context can be different at each location, which may be reflected in the relationship with its spatial neighborhood.

The study of spatial context and dependencies has attracted increasing attention in the machine learning community, with studies on spatial context embeddings and spatially explicit auxiliary task learning. In this study, we seek to merge these streams of research. We propose the positional encoder graph neural network (PE-GNN), a flexible approach for better encoding spatial context into GNN-based predictive models. PE-GNN is highly modular and can work with any GNN backbone. PE-GNN contains a positional encoder, which learns a contextual embedding for point coordinates throughout training. PE-GNN also generalizes the spatial autocorrelation auxiliary learning approach to continuous spatial data. We train PE-GNN by constructing a novel training graph, based on k-nearest-neighborhood, from a randomly sampled batch of points at each training step. This forces the positional encoder to learn generalizable features, as the same point coordinate might have different spatial context (neighbors) at different training steps.

2. Related Work

Recent years have seen a rise of research on applications of neural network models for spatial modeling tasks. Graph neural networks (GNNs) are often used for these tasks with the spatial data represented graphically. GNNs offer flexibility and scalability advantages over traditional spatial modeling approaches such as Gaussian processes. Specific GNN architectures, including Graph Convolutional Networks, Graph Attention Networks, and GraphSAGE, are powerful methods for inference and representation learning with spatial data. Recently, GNN approaches tailored to the specific complexities of geospatial data have been developed. The authors of Kriging Convolutional Networks propose using GNNs to perform a modified kriging task. Another study applies GNNs for a spatio-temporal Kriging task, recovering data from unsampled nodes on an input graph. We look to extend this line of research by providing stronger, explicit capacities for GNNs to learn spatial structures. Our proposed method is highly modular and can be combined with any GNN backbone.

Through many decades of research and applications, a myriad of measures, metrics, and statistics have been developed to cover a broad range of spatial interactions. Measures of spatial autocorrelation, such as Moran's I, are particularly popular. They have already been shown to be useful for improving neural network models through auxiliary task learning, model selection, embedding losses, and localized representation learning. Recent years have also seen the emergence of neural network-based embeddings for geographic information, often trained in an unsupervised fashion.
